title: FLASH v2.0

source.description:
Prepare a reaction for each cDNA or gDNA sample and mix well. Add the components in the order specified below. You can make a master mix (MM) of the rapid alkaline phosphatase (RAP) buffer and enzyme. If you are using the RAP MM, mix
of MM with each sample. Mix thoroughly with a pipette or by tapping to avoid shearing.
AB
1 Component 1X
2 DNA, 10pg - 100ng x μL
3 rAPid Alkaline Phosphatase Buffer 2 μL
4 rAPid Alkaline Phosphatase 1 μL
5 H2O up to 20 μL

source.name: Dual guide RNAs (4µM - targeted to genes or regions to be depleted - crisprRNA and tracr RNA - quantified by RNA Qubit)

source.description: If your starting stock of Cas9 is more than 4μM, you must dilute your stock of Cas9 to 4μM by using 1X Cas9 activity buffer.

source.name: cas9 4µM or higher concentration
10X Cas9 Activity Buffer (500mM Tris pH 8.0 - 1M NaCl - 100mM MgCL2 - 10mM TCEP)

source.description:
Make a Cas9 master mix as described below. Add the components in the order specified to prevent precipitation.
ABC
1 Component 1X ____ X
2 10x Cas9 Activity buffer 3 μL ____ μL
3 Cas9 4μM* 2.5 μL ____ μL
4 dgRNAs 4μM** 3 μL ____ μL
5 H2O 0.5 μL ____ μL
6 Total 9 μL ____ μL
*Remember to dilute your Cas9 stock to 4uM if not already at 4uM. Use 1x Cas9 activity buffer to dilute your Cas9 enzyme if you do need to dilute your stock.
**Remember to dilute your dgRNAs to 4uM using water if needed.
Note: Most experiments for the 2018 FLASH paper were performed at this Cas9 concentration. However, we have demonstrated that lower concentrations work equally well on bacterial isolate DNA. Consult the manuscript for more details.

ABC
1 Component 1X ____ X
2 10x Cas9 Activity buffer 3 μL ____ μL
3 Cas9 4μM* 2.5 μL ____ μL
4 dgRNAs 4μM** 3 μL ____ μL
5 H2O 0.5 μL ____ μL
6 Total 9 μL ____ μL

of the master mix to each of your
blocked DNA samples.

rack. Allow beads to separate on the magnet for 3-5 minutes, or until the supernatant is clear.
Keeping the tubes on the magnet, carefully remove and discard the supernatant.

Prepare the following mixture for each sample. You can prepare the dA-tailing buffer and Klenow fragment ahead of time as a MM. If you prepared dA-tailing MM, add 9.6uL of MM to each sample.

3 dA-Tailing buffer 6 μL
4 Klenow fragment 3.6 μL

source.body:
! The reagents used in this step are very viscous and must be mixed well before using.
! Do NOT make a master mix for this step, although the Ligation Master Mix and Ligation Enhancer may be mixed up to 4 hours before and kept at 4°C.

source.description:
Prepare the following mixture for each sample. Alternatively, if you prepared an adaptor MM with Ligation MM and Ligation Enhancer, add 31uL of MM to each sample and then add 2.5uL of adaptor to each sample.
AB
1 Component 1X
2 dA-tailed sample from part IV 60 μL
3 NEB Ultra II Ligation Master Mix 30 μL
4 NEBNext Ligation Enhancer 1 μL
5 NEBNext Adaptor 1:100 or 1:300 dilution* 2.5 μL
6 Total 93.5 μL
Note: Adaptor dilution of 1:100 works for an initial DNA input up to 100 ng. A 1:300 dilution is recommended for an initial DNA input of under 10 ng. The subsequent cleanup step should remove all extra adaptor and adaptor dimers.

AB
1 Component 1X
2 dA-tailed sample from part IV 60 μL
3 NEB Ultra II Ligation Master Mix 30 μL
4 NEBNext Ligation Enhancer 1 μL
5 NEBNext Adaptor 1:100 or 1:300 dilution* 2.5 μL
6 Total 93.5 μL

source.name: NEBNext Adaptor for Illumina
NEBNext Ultra II Ligation Module - 96 rxns

Allow the beads to air dry for

source.description: Thaw a TruSeq i5/i7 barcode plate or other TruSeq primers, and choose barcodes for each sample. Take note of plate color/barcodes to be used. DO NOT use the same barcode for more than one sample in a sequencing run. Dual unique TruSeq barcodes are preferable.

source.description: Spin down plate or tube strips briefly to collect liquid to bottom of the well.

Prepare the following mixture for each sample. You can make a master mix of USER enzyme and Q5. If doing this, add 28µL of MM to your 25µL sample.

2Ligated sample + TruSeq indexing primers from part VI25 μL
3 NEBNext Ultra II 2X Q5 PCR Master Mix 25 μL

5 Total 53 μL

Using optical PCR strip tubes which are separated from each other so that they can be removed from the thermocycler one at a time, add KAPA amplification MM and Illumina P7 and P5 (5sol-20 and 5sol-21) primers at 5µM to your samples as below. You can make a master mix of KAPA master mix and primers.
AB
1 Component 1X
2 Amplified and indexed DNA 23 μL
3 Kapa amplification master mix 25 μL
4Illumina P5 and P7 5uM primers 2 μL
5 Total 50 μL

source.name: Kapa HiFi Real-Time Amplification Kit
Illumina P5 and P7 primers 5uM combined; P5: 5’ AATGATACGGCGACCACCGAGATCT P7: 5’ CAAGCAGAAGACGGCATACGAGAT

source.description:
AB
1 Component 1X
2 Amplified and indexed DNA 23 μL
3 Kapa amplification master mix 25 μL
4Illumina P5 and P7 5uM primers 2 μL
5 Total 50 μL
Cap all tubes with optical caps. Do not write on the caps.

Set up the following PCR conditions:
ABC
1 Temperature Time Cycles
2 98°C 45 sec 1
3 98°C 15 sec 20
4 60°C 30 sec
5 72°C 1 min 30 sec
6 Plate read
7 72°C 30 sec
Run the program, and watch until your sample either:
1. Crosses the standard (STD) 2 threshold
2. Starts to plataeu
Then pull your sample out DURING THE 72C 30sec INCUBATION after the plate read. It is critical to pull it out during this step, and not when it is denaturing or annealing.
If your sample still has not reached the STD 2 by 20 cycles, let the program finish.
Alternatively, if you have many samples, you can simply apply 10 cycles to all, and evaluate if you need further amplification later.
You may want to take note of the unique number of cycles each sample needed to reach the STD 2 threshold.

ABC
1 Temperature Time Cycles
2 98°C 45 sec 1
3 98°C 15 sec 20
4 60°C 30 sec
5 72°C 1 min 30 sec
6 Plate read
7 72°C 30 sec
Place your labeled samples in the RT-PCR thermocycler.

Add
of STD 2 to a clean optical PCR tube.
Equilibrate clean SPRI beads to room temperature and vortex well to mix.

Quantify by HS DNA Qubit

source.name: Qubit 1X dsDNA High Sensitivity Assay Kit

source.description: Run a fragment analysis, such as with the HS DNA Bioanalyzer. You are expecting a fragment trace that is characterized by sharp peaks in the 250-650 range. A successful FLASHed sample trace looks approximately like this: (lower marker in green, upper marker in purple)

source.name: Bioanalyzer chips and reagents (DNA High Sensitivity kit)

source.description: If there is a large spike at ~138 bp, this is indicative of adaptor dimer in the sample. We recommend: 1) Additional SPRI clean-ups with a sample:bead volume ratio of 1X (as many as necessary for removal of dimers), or 2) size selection to 250-650bp with the BluePippin on a 2% gel.
If pooling multiple samples, use the concentration of DNA between 250-650bp for normalization.
When satisfied with the quality of your pooled/individual library, proceed with quantitative PCR and sequencing.
Normalize your cDNA or gDNA to anywhere between 10pg-100ng. For most samples, we recommend 5-10ng input.

Incubate at
for
with heated lid OFF.

Add
sodium orthovanadate (competitive inhibitor of phosphatases) to the quench the reaction and mix well with a pipette or by tapping.

source.name: Sodium Orthovanadate (Vanadate) - 1 ml

10X Cas9 Activity Buffer (500mM Tris pH 8.0 - 1M NaCl - 100mM MgCL2 - 10mM TCEP)

description: FLASH is a crispr-cas9 technology that enriches for targeted sequences in sequencing libraries. The initial DNA sample undergoes a blocking step that removes of the 5’ phosphoryl groups of the DNA fragments, resulting in a product that is not amendable for downstream adaptor ligation or amplification via standard Illumina-based library preparation. The subsequent incorporation of targeted CRISPR-cas9 library exposes the desired regions of interest, allowing them to be processed into a library. For more information on methods and results, please see the FLASH paper. For FLASH guide RNA design help, please see our github.
